RT mutants were degraded after incorporation of the precursor polyprotein into the virions. mutations in residues 271 and 274 would reduce the stability of RT inside the viral particles, rendering it susceptible to viral protease. RT exists as an equilibrium mixture of monomers and dimers. the p66/p66 heterodimer is the most stable and the p51/p51 homodimer is the most unstable [40]–[43]. RT degradation may be ascribed to the inhibition of RT p66 dimerization by the mutations. alanine substitutions at residue 271 or 274 of HIV-1 RT could cause conformational changes, rendering RT unstable and susceptible to viral protease. this could be explained by different proteolytic stability of RT in vitro and in virions. these findings may prove useful in anti-HIV drug design and vaccine development.
